description:
This can't go in until after 3.3 is released.

Also, I hope I didn't lose much in my messing about with the pull request after I made a mistake on where I committed something.
title: [3.4] Boolean objects draft

content.raw: This sentence is phrased a little awkwardly. How about: "The ``intersection`` and ``union`` can be used to make data objects that are the logical intersection and union of other data objects. These should be more performant that a sequence of calls to the ``+`` or ``&`` operators. For instance:
content.html: This sentence is phrased a little awkwardly. How about: "The intersection and union can be used to make data objects that are the logical intersection and union of other data objects. These should be more performant that a sequence of calls to the + or & operators. For instance:

content.raw: It would be nice if you made these two runnable scripts that generate plots, otherwise it's hard to visualize what these examples are doing.
content.html: It would be nice if you made these two runnable scripts that generate plots, otherwise it's hard to visualize what these examples are doing.

content.raw:
Rather than using asserts, I think it's better style to write checks like this explicitly, i.e.:

```
if not isinstance(other, YTSelectionContainer3D):
     raise YTBooleanObjectError("Boolean operations on data objects are only supported between two 3D data objects.")
```

This is more verbose, but has the benefit that the check can't be turned off at runtime, and also makes it possible to use a custom exception. It's also clearer to the user that this is an issue with their use of yt rather than a bug in yt itself. More opinions on this here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/944592/best-practice-for-python-assert

If you're wedded to the asserts, then you should at least add descriptive error messages to all the asserts in this section.
content.html:
Rather than using asserts, I think it's better style to write checks like this explicitly, i.e.:

if not isinstance(other, YTSelectionContainer3D):
     raise YTBooleanObjectError("Boolean operations on data objects are only supported between two 3D data objects.")

This is more verbose, but has the benefit that the check can't be turned off at runtime, and also makes it possible to use a custom exception. It's also clearer to the user that this is an issue with their use of yt rather than a bug in yt itself. More opinions on this here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/944592/best-practice-for-python-assert

If you're wedded to the asserts, then you should at least add descriptive error messages to all the asserts in this section.

content.raw: bikeshed: `YTBooleanContainer` maybe? Right now the name doesn't indicate that it's a data container like the other data container classes.
content.html: bikeshed: YTBooleanContainer maybe? Right now the name doesn't indicate that it's a data container like the other data container classes.

content.raw: Check if the of field parameters dicts on the two parent objects match. If they do, pass to the boolean data object, if they don't, raise an error.
content.html: Check if the of field parameters dicts on the two parent objects match. If they do, pass to the boolean data object, if they don't, raise an error.

content.raw: maybe `YTIntersectionContainer3d`?
content.html: maybe YTIntersectionContainer3d?

content.raw: Rather than defining it twice, we should wait until PR 2259 is merged and then delete this.
content.html: Rather than defining it twice, we should wait until PR 2259 is merged and then delete this.

content.raw: nit: imports like this should be offset by 4 spaces, not 8.
content.html: nit: imports like this should be offset by 4 spaces, not 8.

content.raw: Maybe it would be worthwhile to add a comment to the header of this file explaining the use of morton indices in these tests? They're a little bit mysterious to me still.
content.html: Maybe it would be worthwhile to add a comment to the header of this file explaining the use of morton indices in these tests? They're a little bit mysterious to me still.

content.raw: maybe add docstrings explaining what the selections do, for each `BooleanSelector` subclass? That way you can clearly spell out the difference between NEG and NOT, for example.
content.html: maybe add docstrings explaining what the selections do, for each BooleanSelector subclass? That way you can clearly spell out the difference between NEG and NOT, for example.

content.raw: Maybe `ChainedIntersectionSelector`, which makes it easier to see how this relates to the high-level API.
content.html: Maybe ChainedIntersectionSelector, which makes it easier to see how this relates to the high-level API.

content.raw: same here, `ChainedUnionSelector`?
content.html: same here, ChainedUnionSelector?

content.raw: Is this indirection necessary? I think you could only override `__init__` in this class, and then in the two subclasses override `select_bbox` explicitly and then you don't need to define `_select_bbox` at all. Same for all the other functions defined on this class below.
content.html: Is this indirection necessary? I think you could only override __init__ in this class, and then in the two subclasses override select_bbox explicitly and then you don't need to define _select_bbox at all. Same for all the other functions defined on this class below.

content.raw: Overall looks awesome, hope my comments weren't too nitpicky...
content.html: Overall looks awesome, hope my comments weren't too nitpicky...

content.raw:
Ah, that was what I thought too!

Sadly, this is the only way to combine the `gil`/`nogil` that I need.
content.html:
Ah, that was what I thought too!

Sadly, this is the only way to combine the gil/nogil that I need.

content.raw: (Unless you can come up with a better way, for which I would be grateful.)
content.html: (Unless you can come up with a better way, for which I would be grateful.)

content.raw: Implement the logic in the `_select_bbox` functions in `with gil` blocks inside `select_bbox` in each of the two subclasses?
content.html: Implement the logic in the _select_bbox functions in with gil blocks inside select_bbox in each of the two subclasses?

content.raw: Tried it -- you can't `cdef` inside the `with gil` block, so it ends up leaving around refcounted variables.  Might be a Cython bug, but I couldn't figure out a way around it.
content.html: Tried it -- you can't cdef inside the with gil block, so it ends up leaving around refcounted variables. Might be a Cython bug, but I couldn't figure out a way around it.

content.raw:
Could this be written 
```
#!python

return self.sel1.select_bbox(left_edge, right_edge) and \
       self.sel2.select_bbox(left_edge, right_edge)
```

and likewise for the other functions below?
content.html:
Could this be written 

return self.sel1.select_bbox(left_edge, right_edge) and \
       self.sel2.select_bbox(left_edge, right_edge)

and likewise for the other functions below?
